The three-minute and six-second video was published on Facebook here on September 22, 2020.
It has been viewed over 15 million times and shared more than 136,000 times.

The post does not have a caption but the footage features a Pakistani and Indian flag overlaid above the troops, purporting to indicate that the tug of war is between the Pakistani and Indian militaries.

An Urdu song can also be heard in the background which translates partly as: “We are Pakistani mujahid (holy warriors), we are the guardians of this land….If anyone dares challenge us, even by mistake, we will bury him.”

The video was also shared here and here on Facebook in November and December 2020 alongside captions that read “Long Live Pakistan” and “Alhamdu lellah (Praise be to Allah) pakistan is the powerful country of islam…”
A Google reverse image search using video keyframes found that the footage was published on YouTube here in 2012. The channel's username is 31CanadianBrigade.
The video's title reads: “One on one soldier Tug of War, Canada vs USA.”

The video description reads: “Prior to the departure of 31 Canadian Brigade Group (31 CBG) personnel from Camp Atterbury, Indiana, Canadian soldiers observed US National Guard soldiers playing an interesting version of the game Tug of War.”
Below is a screenshot comparison of the video shared in the misleading Facebook post (L) and the 2012 YouTube video (R):
Windsor Star, a Canadian newspaper, also published a report about the tug of war between US and Canadian soldiers here on March 28, 2012.
The report embeds the footage and includes comment from a Canadian soldier who confirms that the video was taken during a joint training exercise in the US state of Indiana.
A closer look at the soldiers’ uniforms also reveals that US and Canadian flags are pinned on the sleeves.
Below is a screenshot of the video with the soldier's flags magnified.
Below is another screenshot of the video in which Canadian and US flags are clearly visible on the soldier's uniforms.
A spokesperson for the Canadian military also confirmed that the footage shows a friendly tug of war game between a Canadian and US soldier in Indiana in March 2012.
In an email to AFP on January 13, 2021, the spokesperson added that the YouTube account that published the original video is an old channel for the Canadian brigade that participated in the game.
